channel.title: Using the Java Docs
channel.description:
The Java docs can me the most powerfull asset to a good java programmer, but it can also be a very confusing thing for a new one.
First off the latest docs can be found at: [code]http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/[/code] http://img149.imageshack.us/my.php?image=screenshotdu4.png This is the main page, and the start of our small but educational journey.
We now choose our package.Different packages allow us to do different things.Got example [i]java.io[/i] allows us to do input and output whilst [i]java.maths[/i] allows us to do maths equations more easier.We are going to choose [b]java.lang[/b] which is there by default.Now we are prsented with numerous things all of which are usefull i nthere own regard.Basicly we choose what type of thing we wan't to do and click the interface or class that has what you wan't do do with it included.So say if we wanted to do System operations like telling the time, we choose System in the class summary.http://img246.imageshack.us/my.php?image=screenshot1vs3.png <-- (scroll down a slight bit).
In this area of the documents we get a description, method summary and field summary as ell as a few other tools like inherited methods.The Field goes after the class when using it.
[code]System.out.println("Hello");[/code] System being the class, out being the field and println being the method.Scroll down to method detail and find a random one.In some cases the field name isn't needed, like for setProperty(). [img]http://img440.imageshack.us/img440/7383/screenshot2no8.png[/img] The console() detailed method tells us what it returns, when it was first implemented , paremeters and finally what it throws.These are all usefull for a java programmer.
Sorry for the examples not always being exactly what i explained..i'm just a bit tired.Enum.

item.title: Using the Java Docs
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I found these a pain in the ass at first. But yeah, they are handy once you get the idea of how to use them.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Goat_Spirit wrote:

Good.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the Java Docs
item.dc:creator: @Enum Enum
item.description:
@Enum wrote:

1337h4x:

And there arn’t only javadocs for java. People can make their own, lyk the arga jdocs.

Great point, but there seperate from the main docs.

On a side note, arga is programmed rather roughly from what i’v seen.

Better do your updates mate. Wink I have dapper, you using edgy? It's very buggy and unstable.

Drapper hehe.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the Java Docs
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Thanks for posting this. The javadocs are definitely one of the best tools for java programmers, and I think it would help a lot of people if they got in the habit of using them earlier on.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the Java Docs
item.dc:creator: @Enum Enum
item.description:
@Enum wrote:

The Java docs can me the most powerfull asset to a good java programmer, but it can also be a very confusing thing for a new one.

First off the latest docs can be found at:

http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/

http://img149.imageshack.us/my.php?image=screenshotdu4.png
This is the main page, and the start of our small but educational journey.

We now choose our package.Different packages allow us to do different things.Got example java.io allows us to do input and output whilst java.maths allows us to do maths equations more easier.We are going to choose java.lang which is there by default.Now we are prsented with numerous things all of which are usefull i nthere own regard.Basicly we choose what type of thing we wan’t to do and click the interface or class that has what you wan’t do do with it included.So say if we wanted to do System operations like telling the time, we choose System in the class summary.http://img246.imageshack.us/my.php?image=screenshot1vs3.png <-- (scroll down a slight bit).

In this area of the documents we get a description, method summary and field summary as ell as a few other tools like inherited methods.The Field goes after the class when using it.

System.out.println("Hello");

System being the class, out being the field and println being the method.Scroll down to method detail and find a random one.In some cases the field name isn’t needed, like for setProperty().

The console() detailed method tells us what it returns, when it was first implemented , paremeters and finally what it throws.These are all usefull for a java programmer.

Sorry for the examples not always being exactly what i explained…i’m just a bit tired.Enum.
